items.title: The sacred and divine to the age of discovery
items.subtitle: Medieval and Gothic art showed many different influences that were seen at differing times across Europe.
items.intro_description: From the late 14th century, the Renaissance spread from Italy through France and Northern Europe bringing a level of technical skill that raised the status of the artist in society and affected many fields of intellectual pursuit. It was the age of discovery. Portuguese and Spanish fleets explored the globe and artists were commissioned by royal patrons who wanted to show off their wealth and sophisticated ideas. Inventions in printing technology led to new ways of sharing art and influenced the subjects that artists chose to depict. Dürer was one of the first great sightseers in European painting creating one the most renowned self-portraits in art.

items.title: Japonism
items.subtitle: (from the French Japonisme, first used in 1872)
items.body:
In France the term Japonisme refers to a specific French style which mainly found expression in the fine arts from 1864,[5] while in England it initially had an impact on the decorative arts, with the first documented pieces of furniture in the Anglo-Japanese style completed in 1862, even if the term Anglo-Japanese was used as early as 1851.

From the 1860s, ukiyo-e, Japanese wood-block prints, became a source of inspiration for many European impressionist painters in France and elsewhere, and eventually for Art Nouveau and Cubism. Artists were especially affected by the lack of perspective and shadow, the flat areas of strong color, and the compositional freedom gained by placing the subject off-centre, mostly with a low diagonal axis to the background.

Japan’s long period of exclusion from the west ended in the mid 19th century, and from 1862 the work of Japanese craftsmen could be seen at world trade fairs.
items.caption: Le Japon artistique, n° 3

items.body: Woodblock prints, porcelain, textiles and lacquer work had a profound impact on many western art movements, including Art Nouveau. Bamboo, carp, wisteria and cherry blossom became part of the decorative repertoire.

items.caption: Arcimboldo's Vertumnus, a portrait depicting Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor

items.body:
Arcimboldo's conventional work, on traditional religious subjects, has fallen into oblivion, but his portraits of human heads made up of vegetables, plants, fruits, sea creatures and tree roots, were greatly admired by his contemporaries and remain a source of fascination today.

At a distance, his portraits looked like normal human portraits. However, individual objects in each portrait were actually overlapped together to make various anatomical shapes of a human.

items.title: Art Nouveau
items.subtitle: Art Nouveau means "new art" in French. Its novelty was in breaking away from the older classical tradition and challenging conventions.
items.intro_description: Art Nouveau interiors were often painted in smooth light colours. Furniture and decorations tended to be dark in order to create contrast with the walls. Influenced by Japanese craft works, the interiors also exhibited elements from this culture which was still new to Europe.

items.body: Glass was one of the materials that could now be made more cheaply and in new forms using processes introduced by the Industrial Revolution in the 19th century. Tired of the old conventions, Art Nouveau artists readily embraced glass in their projects. It became an essential tool in creating luminous living areas and spaces. Large windows and glass roofs helped experiment with dimensions and brightened ambience in Art Nouveau buildings.

items.title: ZURICH - Arthur Segal
items.subtitle: Arthur Segal (13 July 1875 - Jassy, June 1944, London)
items.quote: Arthur's father wanted his son to become a banker and discouraged his early interest in art, but without success
items.body: Arthur Segal is seen as the father of the Jewish avant-garde art scene in Romania. He spent the first years of his life in a town in the northeast of the country. He took no interest in schoolwork and felt excluded because he was Jewish. Arthur’s father wanted his son to become a banker and discouraged his early interest in art, but without success. In 1892 Segal went to Berlin to study painting at the city’s fine arts academy.
